items.title: [identity] Using `scopes` in `AzureCliCredential`

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: This is a new issue that needs to be triaged to the appropriate team.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Is there a reason (security or otherwise) this access token is scoped to a resource?

https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/identity/azure-identity/azure/identity/_credentials/azure_cli.py#L28

I don't fully understand why I need to supply one - I would prefer the access token to have the same access as my user when developing, and have access controlled by RBAC when actually deploying the application.

The issue is that otherwise, if I have some simple code to access blob storage using `DefaultAzureCredential`, I have to pointlessly construct a scope which is only ever used for local development.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I don't know an elegant/proper solution but the behavior I expected was more like

```
COMMAND_LINE = "az account get-access-token --output json{}"
...

resource = _scopes_to_resource(*scopes) if scopes else None
output, error = _run_command(COMMAND_LINE.format(f" --resource {resource}" if resource else ""))
```

Then I can choose to supply a scope for the access token when developing, or have fully access to what my user can access.

Happy to submit a PR for this and the `aio` implementation if I haven't missed something behind the motivation here.

items.title: [Service Bus] Rename ServiceBusManagementClient class to ServiceBusAdministrationClient

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: blocking-release
labels.description: Blocks release

items.body:
The naming guidelines for a client that does resource management but not via the ARM apis, is that it should use the term `Administration` and not `Management`. See https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/issues/1360 for more details

For this reason, the ServiceBusManagementClient class in the new Service Bus package which is currently in preview should be renamed to ServiceBusAdministrationClient

items.title: Cannot get a quota management response from the SDK

labels.name: Mgmt
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the management-plane of the library.

labels.name: Service Attention
labels.description: This issue is responsible by Azure service team.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
- **Package Name**: azure-mgmt-reservations 
- **Package Version**: 0.7.0 installed with --pre via pip3
- **Operating System**: CentOS 7
- **Python Version**: 3.6

**Describe the bug**
When querying for either a single or list of quotas in one of my subscriptions, I get a "Not Found" response from the API every time, even though the data I'm asking for definitely exists and is visible from the Azure web portal.

**To Reproduce**
Here is sample code that I am using which can reproduce the problem, just fill in a valid subscription ID and make sure you've got a shell credential active via 'az login':

```
#!/usr/bin/python3

import sys
from azure.common.client_factory import get_client_from_cli_profile
from azure.mgmt.reservations import AzureReservationAPI
from azure.mgmt.resource import ResourceManagementClient

subscription = "<insert valid subscription ID>"
provider = "Microsoft.Compute"
sku = "standardFSv2Family"
location = "eastus"

client = get_client_from_cli_profile(AzureReservationAPI, subscription_id=subscription)
if client is None:
  print("Error: client creation error.")
  sys.exit(1)
else:
  print("* Client created.")
print("* {0:20s}: {1}".format("Subscription",subscription))
print("* {0:20s}: {1}".format("Provider",provider))
print("* {0:20s}: {1}".format("Location",location))
print("* {0:20s}: {1}".format("SKU",sku))
try:    
  quota_list = client.quotas.list_status(subscription, provider, location)
  for quota in quota_list:
    print(quota)
except:
  exc_info=sys.exc_info()
  print("** List Exception: {0} {1}".format(exc_info[0], exc_info[1]))
try:
  my_quota = client.quota.list_status(subscription, provider, location, sku)
  print(my_quota)
except:
  exc_info=sys.exc_info()
  print("** SKU quota exception: {0} {1}".format(exc_info[0], exc_info[1]))
```

**Expected behavior**
I expect a list of quotas applicable to the subscription, followed by the quota info specific to the given sku, when running the above code.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Additional context**
Actual response from the above code:

```
** List Exception: <class 'azure.mgmt.reservations.models._models_py3.ExceptionResponseException'> Operation returned an invalid status code 'Not Found'
** SKU quota exception: <class 'azure.mgmt.reservations.models._models_py3.ExceptionResponseException'> Operation returned an invalid status code 'Not Found'
```

items.title: Search Documents Readme and Samples issues

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: needs-team-triage
labels.description: This issue needs the team to triage.

items.body:
1.
Section [link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/tree/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents#adding-documents-to-your-index):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/91114334-3d998c00-e6ba-11ea-9440-c191072c7ac9.png)

Suggestion:
Update `client` to `search_client`.

2.
Section [link1](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents/samples/async_samples/sample_data_source_operations_async.py#L67), [link2](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents/samples/async_samples/sample_indexers_operations_async.py#L119):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/91114428-789bbf80-e6ba-11ea-830a-406491229d0b.png)

Suggestion:
Add `await` before code `client.delete_data_source_connection("async-sample-data-source-connection")`

3.
Section [link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents/samples/async_samples/sample_indexers_operations_async.py#L57):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/91114544-c0bae200-e6ba-11ea-875e-c189c20840f0.png)

Suggestion:
Update `indexer-datasource` to `async-indexer-datasource`，make it consistent with the data source name below.

4.
Section [link1](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents/samples/async_samples/sample_data_source_operations_async.py), [link2](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/search/azure-search-documents/samples/async_samples/sample_indexers_operations_async.py):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/91114661-024b8d00-e6bb-11ea-9d76-d42e50e5ec52.png)

Reason:
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'request'.

When using `async with client`, after the internal code execution of with ends, the `__aexit__` method of the client object is automatically called, and the `__aexit__` method calls the `close()` method of the client.
The client in the code is a global variable. After a functional function in the code uses with, the global client will be automatically closed, causing other functional functions to be unable to continue to use the client, causing an exception.

Suggestion:
Remove `async with client:`.
 
@jongio for notification.

items.title: [ServiceBus] Track2 - Re-expose AMQP details on message

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
Given the ask to allow access to AMQP properties such as annotations and headers, there are two proposals at hand.

**Proposal 1**
Flat object.

Pros:
- fewer new object concepts
- less depth
- all props immediately visible.

Cons:
- all props immediately visible.
- amqp/non-amqp confusion at top level


```python
class PeekedMessage(Message):
    def __init__(self, message : AMQPMessage, ...):
        ...
        self.annotations = message.annotations # type: dict[str,str]
        self.headers = message.annotations # type: dict[str,str]
        ...

# accessed as:
message.annotations["foo"]="bar"
```

***Sub-Proposal 1-B***

As above, but amqp_[headers, annotations, etc] naming.

**Proposal 2**
AMQP sub-object.  echoes the design of "ServiceBusReceiver.Session" for function-specific grouping if niche functionality.

Pros:
- logical encapsulation, more communicative.
- keeps core message surface area cleaner.

Cons:
- additional layer of depth/additional concept.
- if we ever introduce circular dependencies between these props, (e.g. A sets B, B sets A) it'll be problematic.

```python
class AMQPMessageProperties(Object):
    def __init__(self, annotations, headers, ...)
        ...
        self.annotations = annotations # type: dict[str,str]
        self.headers = annotations  # type: dict[str,str]
        ...

class PeekedMessage(Message):
    def __init__(self, message : AMQPMessage, ...):
        ...
        self.amqp = AMQPMessageProperties(message.annotations, message.headers, ...) # type: AMQPMessageProperties
        ...

# accessed as:
message.amqp.annotations["foo"] = "bar"
```

items.title: continuation_token is not taken into account

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
Hi,

- **Package Name**: azure-sdk-for-python comos
- **Package Version**: 4.1.0
- **Operating System**: MacOS
- **Python Version**: 3.7.5

**Describe the bug**
In a Proxy container, query_items() method returns a `ItemPaged` object. 
This object has a method `by_page` which can take a `continuation_token`.

However, after reading the source code. This continuation token seems to never be used anywhere.
The workflow seems to be:
* __next__ for PageIterator (take the continuation token)
* self._get_next (propagates the token
* self._fetch_next (of QueryIterable). Take `*args` and do not use them

**To Reproduce**
```py
# cosmosdb_container a ProxyContainer
query = cosmosdb_container.query_items("select * from r", partition_key=NonePartitionKey, max_item_count=1)  # 1 to be sure to have many pages
pager = query.by_page()  # pager starting at first object
first_page = pager.next()
token = pager.continuation_token
real_second_page =  pager.next()
new_pager = query.by_page(token) # pager supposed to start at object number 2
should_be_second_page = new_pager.next()
assert first_object == should_be_second_object  # True but should be False
```

**Expected behavior**
real_second_page should be the same as should_be_second_object (from example from above)

**Additional context**
We were using `options["continuation"]` in previous version which works just fine with these continuation token so it looks like a regression compared to version 3.x

Have a nice day.

items.title: CertificateClient list operations fail with 2016-10-01 client

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
```py
from azure.identity import DefaultAzureCredential
from azure.keyvault.certificates import ApiVersion, CertificateClient

client = CertificateClient(VAULT_URL, DefaultAzureCredential(), api_version=ApiVersion.V2016_10_01)
[_ for _ in client.list_properties_of_certificates()]
```
Raises an error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\temp\kv\repro.py", line 13, in <module>
    props = [_ for _ in client.list_properties_of_certificates()]
  File "...\azure-core\azure\core\tracing\decorator.py", line 83, in wrapper_use_tracer
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "...\azure-keyvault-certificates\azure\keyvault\certificates\_client.py", line 596, in list_properties_of_certificates
    **kwargs
  File "...\azure-keyvault-certificates\azure\keyvault\certificates\_generated\_operations_mixin.py", line 917, in get_certificates
    return mixin_instance.get_certificates(vault_base_url, maxresults, include_pending, **kwargs)
TypeError: get_certificates() takes from 2 to 3 positional arguments but 4 were given
```
The error occurs because the call uses positional arguments and the generated method for version 2016-10-01 doesn't have an `include_pending` parameter:
```py
# 2016-10-01
def get_certificates(self, vault_base_url, maxresults=None, **kwargs)

# 7.0
def get_certificates(self, vault_base_url, maxresults=None, include_pending=None, **kwargs)
```
`get_deleted_certificates` has the same problem.

items.title: [Service Bus] Throw error when Entity Path in connection string does not match what is passed to methods that create senders & receivers

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
In v7 of the Service Bus package, the ServiceBusClient constructor takes connection string which can have the EntityPath specified in it if the user copied it from the policy created for a queue or topic.

The methods to create senders and receivers expect the queue/topic/subscription name to be passed to them.

This issue is to ensure that if there is a mismatch between the two, we should throw an error.

The reason is that a connection string from a policy from one queue/topic when used with a different entity gives a not so helpful error today. We can pre-empt this and throw a meaningful error ourselves instead.

If we are already doing this, please add a comment here sharing the error message and close this issue

items.title: CloudEvent must be an abstraction of the spec, and not JSON specific

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
Again, I'm not saying the current prototype is incorrect, but writting this issue so I'm sure we address the spec explicitly.

Cloud Event is an abstraction of what is an event: https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md

As so, our `CloudEvent` class should not assume any serialization of a `CloudEvent` concept, and model the concept without thinking about the serialization. This implies:
- There should be no `data_base64` attribute, but helpers to set bytes correctly
- Extensions should be treated as explicit extensions (and not simple new attributes at the base level).

Example:
```python
c = CloudEvent(
    id=12,
    source='MyApp',
    type='CreateStuff'
)  # specversion is set by default to "1.0"

c.subject = "mynewfile.jpg"  # I could have set it as kwargs, but for the sake of sample

# Set data. API here could be discuss, we could use `data` property setter for instance
c.set_bytes_data(b"PDF%...", "application/pdf")

# Extensions are allowed aside, to avoid collision
c.extensions["reasonCode"] = 204

c.model # Returns the deserialized model
```

A JSON serialization of this would be:
```json
{
    "id": 12,
    "source": "MyApp",
    "type": "CreateStuff",
    "subject": "mynewfile.jpg",
    "datacontenttype": "application/pdf",
    "data_base64": "ABCDEF_BASE64_OF_PDF",
    "reasonCode": 204
}
```
While a binary mode serialization would be HTTP request
```
ce-id: 12
ce-source
ce-source: MyApp
ce-type: CreateStuff
ce-subject: mynewfile.jpg
ce-datacontenttype: application/pdf
ce-reasonCode: 204

PDF%...
```

items.title: Send EventGrid spec

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
After a lot of investigation and discussion with all party involved, drafting a spec for `send` of EventGrid. We might be near to be done with @t-swpill work, but for clarity needs to be written:

We shall have ONE `send` method only, that accepts different types of content:
- A CloudEvent instance
- A EventGridSchema instance
- A dict, or any type
- An explicit list of the three preceding format

For the later, we shall send the dict "as-is" on the wire, and not try any kind of client-side validation. Example, this is a valid way to send a Cloud Event:

```python
client.send({
   "id": "foo",
   "source": "blo",
   "specversion":"1.0",
   "type": "blie",
   "data": {"joy":True}
})
```

The dict follow the CloudEvent spec, so there is no reason to not send it that way.

Implementation (important) detail: when sending a CloudEvent, we must set the Content-Type to "application/cloudevents-batch+json; charset=utf-8". This means in the dict case, we must detect if the dict is Cloud Event. We recommend using a predicate that checks:
- All required Cloud Event attributest are provided: id/source/specversion/type
- specversion has the value "1.0"

If the dict follow this structure, we send the JSON with `application/cloudevents-batch+json; charset=utf-8`, otherwise we use `application/json`

In case we want to be explicit:
```python
client.send({
       "id": "foo",
       "source": "blo",
       "specversion":"1.0",
       "type": "blie",
       "data": {"joy":True}
   },
   content_type="application/json"
)
```

And list are supported:
```python
client.send([{
   "id": "foo",
   "source": "blo",
   "specversion":"1.0",
   "type": "blie",
   "data": {"joy":True}
},{
   "id": "foo",
   "source": "blo",
   "specversion":"1.0",
   "type": "blie",
   "data": {"joy":False}
}])
```

CC @KieranBrantnerMagee @rakshith91

items.title: [azure-eventgrid] add system event models

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
As discussed, for the EG Track 2 SDK, we still need to generate system event models and discuss whether all of these models will fall under a different namespace. Here is a general list of steps to follow/do:

- The System Event models need to be generated based on their schemas defined in the swaggers in all the Microsoft.* subfolders: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/master/specification/eventgrid/data-plane
- I've already generated the Microsoft.Storage models for testing purposes. In order to generate this, I added the path to the raw swagger in my readme.python_t2.md file here: https://github.com/t-swpill/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/event-grid-track-2/sdk/eventgrid/azure-eventgrid/swagger/README.PYTHON_T2.md .To generate the other models, I think you may need to add the other swaggers as input files in the readme.
- You'll need to import the models into azure/eventgrid/_models.py and add them to the azure/eventgrid/_init_.py file
- You'll need to add all the system event type mappings to the _event_type_mappings variable under the DeserializedEvent model in azure/eventgrid/_models.py. Right now, I just have the variable, but I'm know there's a better way to do it: https://github.com/t-swpill/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/7869363b39860356516933efec375b05df721303/sdk/eventgrid/azure-eventgrid/azure/eventgrid/_models.py#L137

items.body:
Hi All,

I'm searching for how to get tenant list by using Python SDK.
After some research I find out [SubscriptionClient][SubscriptionClient] can get list of tenants which only contain `id` & `tenant id`.

I would like to know is there any other method in Python SDK can list tenants?
Or this maybe a feature in the future.
Many thanks!

items.title: Setting of scheduled enqueue time via Message.schedule is not reflected in Message.scheduled_enqueue_time

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: needs-team-attention
labels.description: This issue needs attention from Azure service team or SDK team

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
- **Package Name**: 
azure-servicebus
- **Package Version**: 
0.50.3
- **Operating System**:
Windows 10
- **Python Version**: 
3.7.7

**Describe the bug**
Setting of scheduled enqueue time via `azure.servicebus.Message.schedule` is not reflected in `azure.servicebus.Message.scheduled_enqueue_time`.

**To Reproduce**
```
import azure.servicebus as sb
message = sb.Message('hi there!')
import datetime as dt
message.schedule(dt.datetime.now(dt.timezone.utc)+dt.timedelta(minutes=5))
message.scheduled_enqueue_time
```

**Expected behavior**
`azure.servicebus.Message.scheduled_enqueue_time` should reflect the time set using 
`azure.servicebus.Message.schedule`.

items.title: Clarify the no-body logs

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
This is the way the network logger is logging the body:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/0021b7b0ba4ee9276f6313631373b0e2d6f584a4/sdk/core/azure-core/azure/core/pipeline/policies/_universal.py#L292

This might be confusing, to make an explicit difference between "there was no body, it was None" and "there was a 4 bytes body with the letters N-o-n-e" ([example](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.python/issues/733)).

The latter is actually something that could happen, if any layer is doing an incorrect `str(None)` at some point in the code, and debugging using pure loggers will be complicated.

This issue is about splitting explicitly the `None` body as a separate line, something like:
```python
elif request.body is None:
    _LOGGER.debug("This request has no body")
else:
    _LOGGER.debug(str(http_request.body))
```

items.title: [Event Hubs] Enabling "File share soft delete" in the storage account for checkpoint store causes slow response.

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue requires a change to an existing behavior in the product in order to be resolved.

items.body:
A storage account disables "File share soft delete" by default as shown in the picture.
If it's enabled, EventHubs checkpoint store extension library will gradually experience slow response. 
According to Storage service team,

_"What is happening here is that most likely versioning or soft delete for blobs/containers is on. Because of this every time you overwrite a blob an object is left behind that makes the number of objects in the service grow. This would eventually be garbage collected but would cause a slowdown before that."_

From SDK's perspective, the Python SDK currently re-uploads the blob content with meta data. We should change to only update the meta data without re-uploading the blob content. Then this problem will disappear even if "File share soft delete" is enabled.

JavaScript SDK team found this problem during their EventHubs long running test and the test storage account happened to have that option enabled.
No Python customer has ever reported it.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/48257664/88981305-82c4cc80-d27a-11ea-8a92-a655463f375c.png)

items.title: msrest.serialization serializes CloudEvent data field object as string

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
I am trying to send a CloudEvent to an Event Grid topic, where CloudEvent is a model which inherits from `msrest.serialization.Model`. The CloudEvent is the following:

```
event = CloudEvent(
                type="Azure.Sdk.Sample",
                source="https://egsample.dev/sampleevent",
                data=CustomSample("custom event")
                )
```

The CustomSample class is:

```
class CustomSample(msrest.serialization.Model):
    _validation = {
            'a': {'required': True},
    }

    _attribute_map = {
        'a': {'key': 'a', 'type': 'str'},
    }

    def __init__(self, a):
        self.a = a
```

When the CloudEvent is serialized to send to the Event Grid service, the CustomSample object in the data field is serialized into a string. This means that, when I try to deserialize the CloudEvent again on the receiving side, the data is not deserialized into the original CustomSample object again.

For example, this code:
```
serialized_event = CloudEvent.serialize(event)
print("serialized: {}".format(serialized_event))
deserialized_event = CloudEvent.deserialize(serialized_event)
print("deserialized: {}".format(deserialized_event))
```

results in this output:

```
serialized: {'id': '73cdccf6-e4b0-485f-8965-d27bad36bedc', 'source': 'https://egsample.dev/sampleevent', 'data': "{'a': 'sample event'}", 'type': 'Azure.Sdk.Sample', 'time': '2020-07-30T19:19:39.165385Z', 'specversion': '1.0'}
deserialized: {'additional_properties': None, 'id': '73cdccf6-e4b0-485f-8965-d27bad36bedc', 'data': "{'a': 'sample event'}", 'data_base64': None, 'time': datetime.datetime(2020, 7, 30, 
19, 19, 39, 165385, tzinfo=<isodate.tzinfo.Utc object at 0x000001FF9C64E400>), 'specversion': '1.0', 'dataschema': None, 'datacontenttype': None, 'subject': None, 'source': 'https://egsample.dev/sampleevent', 'type': 'Azure.Sdk.Sample'}
```

When the value of the data field is set to another type, such as an int or dict, it is serialized/deserialized as an int or dict, respectively. I would similarly expect the data field to be serialized/deserialized as a CustomSample object, instead of a string.

items.title: HttpLoggingPolicy should acknowledge the existence of a body

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

items.body:
By design, HttpLoggingPolicy does not log the body of the request. However, this makes debugging complicated in some scenario, when we want at least to know if _any_ body has been sent.

This issue is about adding something like:
```python
                if isinstance(http_request.body, types.GeneratorType):
                    _LOGGER.info("File upload")
                elif http_request.body:
                    _LOGGER.info("A body is sent with the request")
                else:
                    _LOGGER.info("No body was attached to the request")                  
``` 
to at least indicate that something was sent or not.

This is pseudo-code, the PR should think about data/files and all possible kind of body a request can hold.
